Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Methylmercury Interactions with Marine Plankton
Award.AbstractNarration:
Methylmercury (MeHg) causes a variety of adverse health effects in exposed humans and wildlife but its formation and cycling in oceanic waters have not been fully characterized or quantified. This research program seeks to better understand factors controlling the production, fate, phytoplankton uptake, and transfer of MeHg in the marine environment

A combination of laboratory, field studies and modeling efforts will investigate the bioaccumulation, trophic transfer in aquatic food webs, and implications that this may have on the global transport of this potent neurotoxin. Laboratory and coastal field studies of MeHg interactions with different types of phytoplankton, interaction with specific organic compounds, effects of light and temperature are all expected to influence MeHg binding and or uptake into phytoplankton.

Broader impacts of the work include:
1) provision of policy relevant information in support of monitoring and evaluation efforts for control of anthropogenic mercury releases;
2) informing education on marine conservation and sustainability by developing a case study on mercury in the marine environment; and
3) training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists

POR.DRECONTENT:
Methylmercury (MeHg) is a form of mercury that is commonly produced by several types of bacteria residing in marine and freshwater environments. This form of mercury is released from these bacteria into marine waters and tends to be the form of mercury that builds up in aquatic food chains, often to very elevated levels in some apex predatory fish (e.g., tunas, swordfish, sharks). It is, in fact, the most prominent of all metals that displays biomagnification in aquatic food chains, meaning its concentrations in the tissues of predators exceed those in their prey. MeHg is also known to be toxic to all organisms and its high concentrations in seafood has deleteriously affected health in human seafood consumers. Despite the importance of its build-up in aquatic food chains, few studies have documented the factors that influence its entry into the base of marine food chains, although its bioaccumulation in freshwater plankton is well documented.  

This study therefore evaluated the biological chemical factors that influence MeHg’s uptake by marine phytoplankton (unicellular algae that serve as the base of most marine food chains). Various laboratory and field studies were conducted to evaluate the influence of dissolved organic carbon, temperature, and salinity on the bioaccumulation of methylmercury by diverse species of marine phytoplankton representing the major taxonomic groups of algae in the ocean.  The rate of uptake of MeHg by these algal cells, the extent to which they concentrated this compound, and its site of deposition in these cells was evaluated. In addition, experiments were conducted in which the trophic transfer of methylmercury to marine zooplankton (copepods) was evaluated.

It was found that MeHg can adsorb to algal cells very effectively, and that its bioconcentration in these cells was comparable to, or for some species greater than, that of inorganic mercury. Uptake of MeHg was not directly affected by light or temperature and appears to be a passive process for most species examined. This means that the cells did not need to expend energy in acquiring MeHg out of seawater. Bioconcentration factors increased significantly with surface-to-volume ratios of the algal cells; thus smaller cells had greater concentration factors than larger cells. In this way, methylmercury does not significantly differ from other metals. The volume/volume bioconcentration factors of methylmercury ranged up to 6 million, meaning the cells were 6 million times more enriched than ambient seawater in MeHg.  These cells are therefore highly enriched sources of MeHg for herbivores. Experiments also determined the influence of specific dissolved organic compounds on the bioaccumulation of methylmercury by phytoplankton. Of the organic compounds examined, only the thiol-containing compounds, most particularly glutathione, had a pronounced effect on the bioaccumulation of methylmercury (decreasing the bioconcentration factor and the uptake rate constant).

When marine zooplankton ate these MeHg-enriched cells, they typically assimilated about 80% of the MeHg that they ingested, and assimilation efficiencies were significantly correlated with the cytoplasmic distribution of the methylmercury in the algal cells. Methylmercury uptake in copepods from the aqueous phase was low and modeling shows that nearly all this compound acquired by this zooplankter is from algal diet. Further the loss rate of MeHg from copepods was very low, much lower than that of inorganic Hg. The higher assimilation efficiency and much lower loss rate of MeHg (compared to inorganic mercury) in copepods accounts for the finding that nearly all of the mercury in marine animals is in the methylated form.

The findings of these experiments provide the first interspecific comparisons of methylmercury uptake in marine phytoplankton. They also show that phytoplankton can serve as especially enriched sources of methylmercury for herbivorous animals, including zooplankton which can then transfer this compound on to higher trophic levels, including fish.

As a consequence of high Hg concentrations and high human consumption, tunas provide more Hg (~40%) to the U.S population than any other source. Reduced Hg emissions in North America have decreased Hg concentrations in North Atlantic waters and investigating whether changes propagate up to top predators is key to evaluating the benefits of emission reduction efforts. In this regard, we analyzed the MeHg content in 1,292 Atlantic bluefin tuna captured in the Gulf of Maine between 2004 and 2012. While all fish had elevated MeHg concentrations (0.25 to 3.15 mg kg-1), MeHg decreased significantly at a rate of 2% per year from 2004 to 2012, reflecting comparable declines in mercury emissions from power plants in N. America during this period. Thus, efforts to decrease atmospheric Hg loading have propagated up marine food webs to a commercially important species. This is the first evidence to indicate that these efforts have resulted in lower Hg concentrations in tuna, the biggest Hg contributor for human consumers.
